qas.question: Which emperor decreed that all Romans must sacrifice to traditional gods?
What religious group was exempt from sacrifices?
What oath was a requirement of the emperor's decree?
What was the Decian decree meant to root out?
What happened to the decree after a year?

context: In the wake of religious riots in Egypt, the emperor <a0_0>Decius<a0_0/> decreed that all subjects of the Empire must actively seek to benefit the state through witnessed and certified sacrifice to "ancestral gods" or suffer a penalty: only <a1_0>Jews<a1_0/> were exempt. Decius' edict appealed to whatever common mos maiores might reunite a politically and socially fractured Empire and its multitude of cults; no ancestral gods were specified by name. The fulfillment of sacrificial obligation by loyal subjects would define them and their gods as Roman. Roman oaths of loyalty were traditionally collective; the <a2_0>Decian oath<a2_0/> has been interpreted as a design to root out individual <a3_0>subversives<a3_0/> and suppress their cults, but apostasy was sought, rather than capital punishment. A year after its due deadline, the <a4_0>edict expired.
